ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to read and write better in Korean. I also learned about the history of Korea, Korean literature, and more through this course.
Korean skills.
Formal korean writing, grammar
Mainly reading, writing, and vocabulary skills in this course.
I learned advanced Korean writing and improved my range of vocabulary.

I learned to use a lot more professional and formal language, compared to a lot of the more casual terms and phrases I was used to. You also get to learn about Korean history and culture through the reading we do, so that was also very interesting.
Both a lot of new vocabulary as well as better understanding of Korean history and current affairs.
I was able to not only able to improve my Korean skills and expand my vocabulary, but learn a lot about the country and its history as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this course is the breadth of topics we studied. The weakness of this course is the lack of organization and unclear deadlines.

Strength is that you get to learn a lot of Korean and interact with a lot of Korean that isn't common to people who live in the US. A weakness is that this course is very loosely organized so you can feel lost at times.

Strengths: tailored to each student
Weaknesses: syllabus is a little disorganized

Strengths: very good for helping students improve on writing and reading skills. Interesting material 
Weaknesses: the instructor was very disorganized and it was unclear what homework was due when.

The course is great in that a comprehensive overview of all the major historical events and social issues are provided throughout the course. The writing assignments are also well designed to make you reflect on the material. However, the course could be more organized, with clearer due dates and ways to submit your work. I would have loved it if Professor was able to provide feedback on all of my work. I feel I have learned more through writing a lot rather than through targeted feedback.

I did get to learn a lot of vocabulary and practice writing in Korean, however I felt that the course itself was not very organized. Many of the assignments were not on canvas and were checked by the TAs.
Maybe a little disorganized

Strengths of the course include a high emphasis on building core vocabulary and advanced grammar skills, as well as strong support from the professor and the TA's/ 
Some weaknesses include some level of disorganization, such as not having a clear place to check assignments and a place to turn them in. The class is also designed to cater to Korean Americans or Koreans from Korea in general, but foreign or American students who do not have a connection to Korea may find it difficult to adjust to it.

The course was organized with a schedule, but the day to day running of the course was not helpful to learning. Some days it was unclear which words we should study and where to send homework because the Canvas assignments were not updated. There was not a lot of feedback in class or any grades received until towards the end which could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because it definitely pushes you to learn more vocab, but the course would have been much better if it were more organized. I understand that the professor hurt her arm this semester, but I was in the dark about how little or much I was improving due to the lack of feedback.
Yes, if you want to continue using Korean at Yale or improve your Korean skills.
Yes, good opportunity to learn korean
Yes, if they need it for the certificate or if they tested into L5 for a language requirement.

I would recommend this course if you are looking to improve your writing ability in Korean. I would, however, not recommend it if you have finished middle school equivalent education in Korea, as I wish the intellectual challenge was greater. The course really is about how much you want to improve your Korean. If you try harder, you will become a better writer.
Yes, because it's a great way for your Korean skills to improve while learning about Korea.
I would recommend Koreans or Korean Americans to take it but not students learning Korean in their own will.
No
